23rd September 1933.
Shanghai.
Personal & Confidential.
Letter No.
Mr.
Pacific American
Pio Amerian Airweyst,
New York.
Dear Mr. Morgan,
This is thefirst opportunity
that I have had to
morning)since reggipt of your letter regarding Howard.
is an extremelyletter for me to write because of my warm personal
friendship for Howard, and the personal gratification which I
would have in being associated with him.
In my opinion, he is
qualified in every way to represent Fan American Airweys as
Division Manager of the Company's Fer Eastern operation.
He hes
the complete confidence of
every one with whom he came in contact
during his stay in china.
He has a good general knowledge of
Chinese economicz and
political affairs, and he is possessed of
a happy faculty
of getting along with the Chinese.
I hope you
will pardon my frequent reference to this quality; as a matter of
Some-one has defined the word "gentleman" as a *man
who is always
considerate of others!
is ho country which
I have ever visited where the quality breeding and gentlemanly
conduct is as important as in China.
A report of the slightest
affront to the lowest coolie will quickly travel to the highest
officials, and the party guilty of
such
conduct toward any Chinese
will find
himself blocked in any undertaking which he may attempt
without evelt knowing the reason.why such obstacles are thrown in
his way.
Howard is keenly awere of this sensitiveness and pride
on the part of
the Chinese.
I wodid never have to worry about his
conduct in that regard.
He is correct in his statementll that he has had
considerably experience in conducting negotiations with Chinese
officials.
In those negotiations he was tactful and straight
forward; he is inclined to take things very seriously and to
carry his problems home with himto worry over all night, which
in my opinion is a weakness.
Howard has undoubtedly received
other offers to return to Chine as representative of various
concerns desiring to sell products to
the Chinese Government.
He would undoubtedly rather join Pan American Airways.
He is
he is in no
sense a high
pressure salesmen,
entirely in his wearing qualities.
Answering the 3 points enumerated in your letter
specifically:-

(2 )
Mr. S.. Morgan, President, New York. Sept. 24th.
1) In my opinion Howard is qualified for the position
for which he is applying.
2) I do not believe that a second man is necessary at this
this time.
If we should commence operations
to Manila
and Trans-Pacific, a Devision Manager would be required
to cover a very extensive system, and there should be
in my opinion a competent man in cherge at all times
at Shanghai or where ever our Far Eastern headquarters
may be established.
3) If Howard should be selected, I think a fair and adequate
compensation for him would be the same salary
which he
drew from the Department of Commerce, the amount of which
you can easily determine by consulting Leighton Rogers.
The figure which Howard mentioned of G.$7,500 appears to
me about
correct, and would have the additional merit of
under him, This whole
upon my
return to New York along with many other problems
having to do with personel and organization.
If in your opinion it is advisable to employ Howard now
because of other offers he is considering or for any
other reason, I would suggest that he be given an opportu-
nity to nity to fly over the greater part of the routes operated
by the Pan Anerican system, and be also given a thorough
training in Pan American methods, executive,
engineering,
operations, comminications and traffic, and
that he then
be sent to
china with a view of developing him as a No.2
man in
the Far East division, fully capable of filling
the No.l position.
At this point,
I believe that it is my duty to say to
you at the present writing
that I am entirely satisfied with the
position which I occupy in the Pan American organization, that I
believe that we shall be successful in our negotiations,
and that
I shall be very glad of an oppotunity to return to the Far East
for the Company.
It is my desire to complete the contracts
which I was sent over here to negotiate and
then return to New
York for the purpose of discussing,
in details many problems of
an economical, political and organzing nature which cannot be
carried
out by correspendence.
I would then like to have
an @portunity to caciver
above outlined for Howard.
pon to the too of the one
would then like to return to the
Far East bringing Mrs. Bixby and our teo youngest daughters with
us, leaving
the two older girls at Farmington to finish their
education.
I am writing so agh fully concerning my personal
affairs because I believe that you are entitled to know what
I have in my mind for the future, ani so far as that programme
may
effect
the Company's business.
It appears now as though I
will not be able to complete the work here in less than two
months as a minimum.

( 3)
Mr. S. V. Morgan, President, New York.
Assuming now that you are satisfied with my efforts on
then it will
be advisable to employ Howard and sent him out here to take my
place while I am home and in any event to provide
the Company
with a man who is capable of doing my job.
With
all due modesty,
there is no one now in the present
organization how here who is
qualified to succeed me. That
condition is one which should not
exist in any
well organized Company.
Howard in my opinion has
necessary
10 he Division Manager In the rar Bast, but he undoubtedly
to represent the Pan American organiza-
needs
traning and experience in Pan American methods ( as I do also) in
order to be of maximum value
to the Compeny.
With kindest regards,
Very sincerely yours,
H. B. Bixby.
